Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the impact of Sen. Sherrod Brown's vote on the government takeover of health care by labeling it as the "deciding vote."
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support to definitively state that Sen. Sherrod Brown cast the deciding vote on the government takeover of health care.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the definition of a "deciding vote" is clear and universally agreed upon.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that suggests Sen. Sherrod Brown's vote was not the deciding vote, as there were other senators who also voted in favor of the legislation.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a clear explanation of how Sen. Sherrod Brown's vote can be considered the deciding vote.
Contradict fact: The claim may contradict the fact that Sen. Sherrod Brown's vote was just one of many votes in favor of the health care reform legislation.
